fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45324].
  {panel}

I was conducting some Space maintenance in order to identify empty Confluence Spaces.

With react.ui.spacenav enabled, the "Simplified Navigation" appears, containing tabs for "Overview", "Pages" and "Blogs".

For one of our Spaces, the "Overview" tab displayed the following:

!Screen Shot 2016-11-21 at 14.48.52.png!

The "Pages" tab displayed:

!Screen Shot 2016-11-21 at 14.51.41.png!

And the "Blogs" tab displayed:

!Screen Shot 2016-11-21 at 14.52.44.png!

This implied that the Space was completely empty, when in fact it had literally hundreds of pages and attachments. I believe the pages were not shown in the "Pages" tab because the Space homepage was not set.

Erroneously, I subsequently deleted the Space, when it should not have been deleted.

In future I will check *Space Tools > Content Tools > Reorder Pages* and *Space Tools > Content Tools > Attachments* before I delete a Space. However, I find the three empty tabs very misleading and I think a lot of other users will too.

I had to spend a considerable number of hours with Atlassian Cloud support in order to restore an earlier back-up, export the Space and re-import into Confluence.

I suggest making it more explicit that the Space may not be empty in order to avoid wasting users (and Atlassian's) time.

Best wishes,

Gary Bates
fields.summary: When using "Simplified Navigation" Theme (react.ui.spacenav enabled), Confluence sometimes implies that the Space is empty when it is not.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45321].
  {panel}

I'm testing Confluence 6.0.x heavily, since I (and my company) am really looking forward to use the concurrent editing feature.

I have to say though that there is one small thing that will most likely keep me from updating to 6.x and that is the *Discard everyone's changes* option when the first editor chooses to close the page without publishing it. It even reaches that far:

Editor A and B are working on the same page. A closes the page without publishing it, but clicks *Keep draft*. If A starts editing the page again, the draft is there, everything is OK. If, on the other hand, B closes the page and selects *Discard everyone's changes*, this will alter A's draft as well, removing everything A has worked on.

There should at least be a way (or automatism) for all other concurrent editors to save their work or either some sort of a voting mechanism.

There will be nothing more frustrating than working heavily on a page and then get the own work "destroyed" (accidentally or on purpose, doesn't matter) by another person. 

I already expressed my concern about this way of doing it while Confluence 6.0 was still in EAP, but sadly you did not listen (at all).

So... to set Collaborative editing as the new feature of all features (which it is... IMHO), PLEASE, for gods sake, rework the way changes are discarded!
fields.summary: Possibility to vote for discard or save own changes before discarding everyone's work

  {panel}

In our confluence instance it´s easy to start using confluence for most users. But the key of working in confluence is to know which macros you can/should use. And that information is hard to see as a new user (or existing one) as the features are "hidden" in the + -> other macros menu. Also it takes many clicks to get to the correct macro sometimes...

And it takes time to get the knowledge on which macros should be used...

So my suggestion to fix this is to take inspiration from the ribbon used in office. Imaging having a similar menu in confluence where you could group the macros/plugins and having a small image for each macro for example.

!ribbon.png!

But since you have user data of users: why not also add a menu group bar with the "top used macros", trending macros, admin suggested macros aswelll..

And also add to the most right in the menu a quick search for macros, which could function just like the Search tool "Search JIRA admin" which is used when logging in to the administration section of lira.

 

By doing the above changes I think the plugin usage in confluence would not only get easier for existing users, but for new users it would boost their confluence usage from the beginning.
fields.summary: Make it easier for users to find and use macros/plugin by improving the edit menu (why not take inspiration from the ribbons in office)

h3. Problem Definition
When users are already watching all space content and they visit a blog within the space, the *Watch this blog* button does not appear (because they are already watching). However, because the button is missing, the user is not aware that they are already watching the blog. This causes confusion for users. 

h3. Suggested Solution
Either grey out the *Watch this blog* button so the user understands they are already watching the blog or add a new icon that says *Watching this blog* like we do with page watches (see CONF-31980 for an example). 

h3. Why this is important
Sometimes users forget which spaces they are watching. This will save users time and frustration trying to figure out why they cannot watch a blog post. 

h3. Workaround 
There is no known workaround.
fields.summary: Add a "Watching this blog" button when users are watching all content in a space

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45262].
{panel}
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, to add a label to a page one needs to:
 # Click the "Edit labels" icon
 # Type in the full name or a label OR part of the name
 # When presented with a list of suggestions click on the appropriate label
 # Click "Add"
 # Click "Close"

The problem comes from step #3.  Most users think that once they have clicked on a suggested label that it has been added.  Then they click "Close" and the label is not added.

!addlabels.gif|width=550,height=362!

~{color:#505f79}_For example, the label "alpha" is added properly, and "beta" is what users see when they don't click *Add*._{color}~
h3. Suggested Solution

My suggestion is that when a list of label suggestions is presented and the one is selected that it is added automatically.  This would streamline the process and be more intuitive.
 # Click the "Edit labels" icon
 # Type in the full name or a label OR part of the name
 # When presented with a list of suggestions click on the appropriate label
 # Click "Close"

OR, better yet...  Do what JIRA does.  Offer a drop-down list of labels and a field that supports a reactive list of possible matches.  When an item is selected it is added to the field automatically.  The challenge here is that the list of possible labels could be large.
fields.summary: In Labels dialogue, it isn't clear you need to click "add" to save the added labels.

h3. Description

Confluence uses Lucene as the search engine which contains tokenization and stemming. When users use the "Matched phrase search" syntax to search for the term "scheduler statistics", confluence will return the result such as "scheduler statistics", "scheduling statistics", and "scheduled statistics".

The explanation of the "Matched phrase search" in our [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/confluence-search-syntax-158720.html] stated that "Use double quotes to search for content that contains the phrase 'cheese one', or a phrase where 'cheese' and 'one' are the major words:" could cause confusion to the users that confluence will search for the exact terms without tokenization and stemming.
h3. Suggestion

Update the documentation to have a better explanation and add an example on how the tokenization and stemming works with the search syntax.
fields.summary: Update Confluence Search Syntax documentation

h3. Problem Definition
Removing page restrictions on a space is quite time consuming and not user friendly for Confluence administrators especially if there are many restrictions for multiple pages. The user has to click on all locks, preferably in a new tab otherwise they get redirected to a restricted access page, in order to remove all page restrictions to finally get access to the restricted pages.

For instance, it is an issue during Confluence migration as the new admin will not necessarily have permissions to view all pages and the previous user that has set the restrictions does not exist anymore.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide a solution, either as a button in the *Restricted Pages* tab in *Space permissions*, in order to remove all restrictions for one page or all pages at once.

h3. Workaround 
Right-click and open in a new tab when clicking on a lock will allow to stay on the Restricted Pages tab to continue removing all restrictions. However, this workaround is quite time consuming on Confluence instances with lots of restrictions on lots of pages in different spaces.
fields.summary: As a Confluence administrator, I would like to be able to remove page restrictions easily

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45182].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
Using some operations are causing vertical spacing between the macros to be stripped out as {{auto-cursor-target}} class is applied.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Steps to reproduce:
# Start creating a newpage
# Insert a block macro (e.g. the info macro)
# Insert another macro below the first (e.g. another info macro)
# In the space between the two macros, add a line break (in the editor DOM there are now two paragraphs between the macros - one with the {{auto-cursor-target}} class and one without)
# Click on preview and observe that there is vertical spacing between the macros
# Perform one of the "user operations" listed below - do this below the two macros to make the effect clearer to observe (in the editor DOM, both paragraphs between the macros now have the {{auto-cursor-target}} class applied)
# Click on preview and observe that the vertical spacing between the macros has been stripped out

User operations known to cause this issue:
* Wiki autoformatting (e.g. when you type {{h2.}} followed by a space to trigger heading formatting)
* Cutting content (e.g. via {{cmd + v}} shortcut)

This issue is only reproducible on instances that do *not* have the collaborative editing feature enabled.
h3. Expected Results
The spaces are not modified

h3. Actual Results
Vertical spacing between the macros were stripped out.

h3.Workaround
Use operations on the top menu when available, such as selecting a text and making it title, instead of using {{h2.}}.
fields.summary: Vertical spacing removed on preview or publish after certain user operations

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45095].
  {panel}

This happens when a page or attachment is added or deleted while there is an open editing session on a page that either links to the deleted/added page or uses the attachment.

*Steps to reproduce*

* Create a page and insert an image into it. Publish it.
* Click edit to start a new draft.
* Go to the attachments screen of the page and delete the attached image
* Go back to the page and press edit

*Actual behaviour*

* The editor still shows the attachment

*Expected behaviour*

* The editor should show "Unknown attachment"

This happens because the editor format of the page changes even though the page does not get edited. However, Synchrony still has the old editor format.

This is also true for links and macros. For example, deleting a page that was linked to from another page results in this same behavior, as well as deleting a plug-in while one of its macros is used on a page. The page in edit mode still looks like the macro is present even though in view mode it shows up as "Unknown macro."

*Workaround*

The workaround is to publish the page if this happens. Publishing the page forces Synchrony to get the new editor format. The editor format will now say correctly "Unknown attachment" or "Unknown macro" or will point to a non-existent link. The real solution in that case is to remove that part of the page or replace it with the new attachment or link.
fields.summary: Deleting an attachment, page, or plugin outside the editor does not update the editor format

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45045].
  {panel}

h2. Problem summary 
According to https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Page+Restrictions, the Request Access feature works by notifying users who are able to grant restriction access to a page, using this logic in order:
{quote}
# The last person to edit the page
# *All* non-admin users that can set permissions on the page (given that an admin user can always set permissions)
# The page creator
# *All* the space administrators
{quote}

Step 4 is failing. No space admins are notified despite space permission settings. What appears to be happening instead is that a single Confluence superuser (i.e. a member of the "confluence-administrators" group) will be notified. If there are more than one user in this group, the first username on this list, sorted alphabetically, will be sent the request access notification. This user does not need to be in a space administrator for the relevant content. In fact, it doesn't matter who is a space admin on that space, as that configuration does not appear to affect the behavior.

h2. Steps to reproduce
# Set up a Confluence
# Create 5 users:
** UserA
** UserB
** UserC
** SuperX - place this user in confluence-administrators group (superuser)
** SuperY - place this user in confluence-administrators group (superuser)
# Create a space with UserA, so that this user is automatically a space admin
# Create a page with UserB within this space
# Using SuperX, restrict the page so that only SuperX can view it
# Using UserC, try to view the page by going to the page URL directly. The user cannot see it, and will be asked to request access. Click through.

h2. Expected behavior
UserA receives the notification, because although he is not the page creator or the last person to edit the page, he is a full space admin and can set page restrictions.

h2. Actual behavior
SuperX receives the notification, because he is the first superuser alphabetically.

Now rename SuperX to SuperZ, and repeat step 6. Observe that now SuperY is the one who receives the notification, since that is the first superuser alphabetically.

h2. Additional notes
There are actually two parts this is issue:
* Space admins are being ignored in the Request Access logic
* Only one admin is notified, not all, as detailed in the documentation
fields.summary: Request Access feature does not notify space administrators as expected

h4. Workaround
Download and use the [Source Editor Plugin, it is free|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.confluence.plugins.editor.confluence-source-editor/server/overview]. 

You will see, after installing, that when you go to the editor mode of a page, in the right upper corner, you will find *< >* option, click on it, and you will see something similar to:
{code}
....
<ac:structured-macro ac:name="tasks-report-macro">
          <ac:parameter ac:name="spaces">BSP</ac:parameter>
          <ac:parameter ac:name="status">complete</ac:parameter>
          <ac:parameter ac:name="assignees">
            <ri:user ri:userkey="2c9682654373c47f014373caa68a0003"/>
          </ac:parameter>
          <ac:parameter ac:name="spaceAndPage">space:BSP,page:2555905</ac:parameter>
          <ac:parameter ac:name="pages">2555905</ac:parameter>
          <ac:parameter ac:name="labels">meeting-notes</ac:parameter>
          <ac:parameter ac:name="pageSize">10</ac:parameter>
        </ac:structured-macro>
....
{code}
These are the macro parameter, and you can manually change the {{<ac:parameter ac:name="pageSize">10</ac:parameter>}} to 5 and save it. It will now only show 5 tasks. But, first, you need to choose the parameter in the macro, while editing it (in editor mode), for it to show in the source of it.
